results.title: Why?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Tehree Gordon
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Tehree says she is an ordinary Australian, though she was a recipient of the Senior Australian of the Year Award in 2004. In this story, Tehree talks about her passion for wildlife from an early age leading to her founding Jirrahlinga Koala and Wildlife Sanctuary with her partner Hamish. The sanctuary has provided work opportunities and enrichment to people living with disabilities and the elderly.

results.title: To do or not to do.....
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Jock Noble
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Jock Noble, CEO of Diversity@work Australia, talks about the impact having Polio had on his childhood and how that has subsequently shaped his career in helping companies to strengthen through diversity in their workforce.

results.title: River of my Life
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Amira Sabanovic
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Amira describes the course her life has taken - from the ravages of War in her homeland through to the hardships of a refugee’s life in both Europe and Australia before finding acceptance and fulfillment through a supportive workplace.

results.title: My Banquet...
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Chey Scovell
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Chey Scovell recounts his childhood growing up as an Australian born in Malaysia and the last four years of schooling spent in Papua New Guinea. He tells of the culture shock he experienced when returning back to Australia.

results.title: Doors Will Open
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rajani Shrestha
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Rajani Shrestha moved to Melbourne from Nepal in 1992 with her husband and son. Rajani recounts the struggle she faced to find meaningful work in a new country. She tells of her journey which eventually led to her working at AMES Australia.

The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-05. Sound and Colour → MI-05-C02

results.title: Electric sound
results.brief_description: The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction.

constellations_primary.name: Electric Sound Supercut: composers and their distinctive other worlds
constellations_primary.description: Electric sound is commonly associated with science fiction narratives for its auditory oddness, which has symbolised other worldly environments, the unconscious and the 1980s.

results.description: Specific types of movies have a specific sound. Overtime, these associations inevitably become subconscious. The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction, while husband and wife composers Bebe and Louis Barron are credited with creating the first fully realised electronic film score for 50s cult classic Forbidden Planet (1956). From deploying unconventional instruments to early looping and splicing techniques, the legacy of electric sound can still be found today in the works of composers like Danny Elfman.
description_for_label: Specific types of movies have a specific sound. Overtime, these associations inevitably become subconscious. The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction, while husband and wife composers Bebe and Louis Barron are credited with creating the first fully realised electronic film score for 50s cult classic Forbidden Planet (1956). From deploying unconventional instruments to early looping and splicing techniques, the legacy of electric sound can still be found today in the works of composers like Danny Elfman.
